title: RL34443
content: The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) protects participants and beneficiaries in private-sector employee benefit plans. ERISA supersedes state laws except for certain matters like state insurance, banking, and securities laws. It covers pension plans for retirement benefits and welfare benefit plans for other employee benefits. Employers are not required to provide these plans, but must comply with ERISA standards for those that do. ERISA sets standards for who is covered, vesting requirements, and plan regulations. ERISA sets fiduciary standards for employee benefit plans, ensuring funds are handled prudently. It requires informing participants of their rights and financial status, with the right to sue for benefits. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation insures benefits up to a limit. Tax deductions and deferrals are granted to qualified plans meeting IRC requirements. The Department of the Treasury, Department of Labor, and Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation enforce ERISA regulations for pension plans, with specific oversight on contributions, benefits, and distributions. The IRS oversees plan standards, the DOL regulates fiduciary standards, and the PBGC administers the pension benefit insurance program. Employer-sponsored pension plans in the U.S. originated in the late 19th century in the railroad industry. Pensions in the railroad industry were initially seen as gifts for long service, not protected by law. Congress provided tax benefits for pensions in the 1920s, but it did not immediately boost the private pension system. The Revenue Acts of 1938 and 1942 set requirements for tax-qualified pension plans to prevent discrimination in favor of highly compensated employees. During the Second World War, pensions and deferred compensation were exempt from wage controls, allowing employers to offer increased pension benefits to offset limitations on wages. Federal courts in the 1940s mandated that pensions be included in collective bargaining negotiations. Additionally, employers could integrate pension formulas with Social Security benefits to balance income replacement rates. During the 1950s and 1960s, changes in income tax laws and higher marginal tax rates made pensions more valuable to workers, leading to increased adoption of employer-sponsored pensions. The growth of private pension plans during this time also saw instances of misuse of pension assets, prompting Congress to pass The Welfare and Pension Plans Disclosure Act in 1958 for greater transparency. In response to an automobile company terminating its underfunded pension plan in 1963, Congress began considering legislation to protect pension benefits in the private sector. By the early 1970s, bills were drafted by both the House and Senate labor committees to regulate private pension systems. The Senate Finance Committee also asserted jurisdiction due to the tax benefits private pension plans received. ERISA, passed in 1974, incorporated elements from various committees to set standards for employer pension plans. ERISA, signed into law in 1974 by President Gerald Ford, sets standards for employer pension plans. The law falls under the jurisdiction of various committees in Congress, including the House Committee on Education and Labor, the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, the House Ways and Means Committee, and the Senate Finance Committee. Amendments to ERISA have been made over the years to enhance protection for pension plan participants' survivors and spouses, improve funding practices, strengthen the PBGC's finances, adjust tax-deductible contributions, and ensure fairness in tax-favored plans. ERISA, enacted in 1974, protects participants in private-sector pension plans by requiring full funding of earned benefits and prohibiting misuse of pension funds. It also sets limits on age and service requirements for pension eligibility. Defined benefit pension plans are classified by ERISA and the IRC as specifying the benefit paid to participants or the method of determining it. Contributions vary yearly based on funding requirements, with benefits often tied to average pay and years of service. Some plans offer a flat benefit per year of service. Defined benefit pension plans pay a flat benefit per year of service, with the monthly pension benefit calculated based on the years of service. ERISA mandates full funding for these plans, with the employer bearing the investment risk. Assets in the pension trust must cover participant benefits, and qualified plans are protected from creditors in bankruptcy. Defined contribution plans specify contributions, not benefits, providing individual accounts for participants. Defined Contribution (DC) plans provide individual accounts for participants based on contributions and investment gains or losses. Participants bear the investment risk, and DC plans are not insured by the PBGC. The shift from Defined Benefit (DB) plans to DC plans began in the mid-1980s due to factors such as global competition, a mobile workforce preferring portability, and higher costs of maintaining DB plans under ERISA regulations. The decline in Defined Benefit (DB) plans since the 1980s was mainly due to terminations of small plans, with Defined Contribution (DC) plans overtaking in number of plans, participants, and assets by the late 1990s. Many employers have converted traditional DB plans to hybrid plans like cash balance plans. A cash balance plan is a type of defined benefit plan where the employer contributes a fixed percentage of pay to a common trust, with interest paid on the accumulated balance. Participants do not own individual accounts, but rather have a record of their accrued benefits. Cash balance plans guarantee benefits no less than contributions plus interest. In contrast, 401(k) plans are defined contribution plans authorized in 1978, with the first plans established in 1981. A 401(k) plan is an individual account plan where both the employee and employer can make pre-tax contributions. Taxes on contributions and earnings are deferred until withdrawal. Participants can allocate their balances among investment options selected by the employer. The retirement benefit is the account balance, consisting of contributions, interest, dividends, and gains or losses minus fees. Upon leaving the employer, participants can choose to receive these funds. In a 401(k) plan, participants can choose to receive funds through withdrawals or a lump sum. Some plans offer the option to purchase a life annuity, but it is not mandatory. Employees must decide on contribution amounts, investment options, and employer contributions can be fixed or a percentage of pay. Employers can reduce or suspend contributions based on business conditions. 401(k) plans are the most common type of defined contribution plan. ERISA and the pension provisions of the Internal Revenue Code have been amended multiple times since 1974, with significant changes in the Pension Protection Act of 2006 and the Worker, Retiree, and Employer Recovery Act of 2008. ERISA consists of four titles, with Title I focusing on employee rights in pensions and welfare benefit plans. Title III of ERISA assigns administration and enforcement responsibilities to the Departments of Labor and Treasury. Title IV establishes the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. Title I covers employee pension and welfare benefit plans in the private sector, exempting governmental and church plans, as well as plans for workmen's compensation, unemployment compensation, disability insurance, and non-resident aliens. ERISA's policy is to protect plan participants and beneficiaries through disclosure and reporting requirements. ERISA requires disclosure and reporting of financial and other information to participants and beneficiaries of pension and welfare benefit plans. Sections 101 through 111 outline extensive reporting and disclosure requirements, including dissemination of materials like summary plan descriptions and annual reports. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 also made enhancements to reporting and disclosure. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 (PPA) enhanced reporting and disclosure requirements for pension plans, including statements of accrued benefits, annual funding notices, and eligibility to divest employer securities. ERISA mandates plan administrators to provide participants with a summary plan description (SPD) that outlines plan terms and benefits in a clear and comprehensive manner. The SPD must inform participants when they can join the plan and detail the benefits offered. The summary plan description (SPD) must detail when employees can participate in the plan, benefits provided, vesting of benefits, and remedies for denied claims. Any plan alterations must be communicated to participants through a summary of material modifications (SMM) within 210 days after the modification, written in a way understandable to the average participant. ERISA requires that materials be written in a way understandable to plan participants. Courts have determined that certain plan amendments, like establishing or eliminating benefits, are considered material modifications. Section 103 of ERISA mandates certain employee benefit plans to file an annual report with the Department of Labor, serving as a primary source of information for plan operation and funding. The annual report for employee benefit plans must include detailed financial information and be filed with the Department of Labor on Form 5500 within seven months after the plan year ends. Plan participants can request a copy from the plan administrator, and electronic filing of Form 5500 was required by the DOL in 2006. In 2006, the DOL mandated electronic filing of Form 5500 annual reports for employee benefit plans. Plan administrators must provide pension benefit statements to participants and beneficiaries as required by ERISA Section 105. For defined contribution plans, statements must be given quarterly to those with investment control, or annually to those without control. Defined benefit plans must provide statements every three years to eligible individuals. Pension benefit statements must be provided to participants in defined benefit plans upon request, indicating accrued and non-forfeitable benefits. For defined contribution plans, statements should include the value of each investment in the account. Defined benefit plan administrators must also furnish an annual plan funding notice, including information on funding policy, assets, liabilities, participants, and benefits. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) amended ERISA to require plan administrators to provide participants with a notice of their eligibility to divest employer securities held in a defined contribution plan at least 30 days before the divestment date. Participants must be informed of their right to direct divestment and the importance of diversifying their retirement account investments. ERISA requires plan administrators to inform participants about diversifying retirement account investments and limits exclusion from pension plans based on age or service. Employees must have worked at least 1,000 hours in a 12-month period to be considered to have completed a year of service. Alternatively, some plans may require two years of service before participation. ERISA mandates informing participants about diversifying retirement investments and prohibits age-based exclusion from pension plans. Employees need 1,000 hours of work in a year to complete a year of service. Plans may require two years of service before participation. Vesting in certain educational institution plans is 100% after one year, with eligibility at 26 years old or one year of service. ERISA also regulates benefit accrual, defining accrued benefits differently for defined benefit and defined contribution plans. ERISA provides three primary methods for benefit accrual under a defined benefit plan: the "133-1/3 rule," the "3% rule," and the "fractional rule." These rules govern how benefits accrue based on years of service and normal retirement age. ERISA Section 204(g) prohibits plan amendments that eliminate or reduce benefits already accrued in a defined contribution plan. Participants in a defined contribution plan begin accruing benefits once they meet the plan's participation requirements. Employer contributions may be treated differently for vesting purposes than employee contributions. ERISA Section 204(g), known as the "anti-cutback rule," prohibits plan amendments from reducing accrued benefits for plan participants. This includes basic benefits, early retirement benefits, subsidies, and optional forms of benefits. The rule allows freezing or reducing future benefit accruals but aims to protect participants from hindrances in benefit receipt. In Central Laborers' Pension Fund v. Heinz, a retired plan participant's benefits were suspended following a plan amendment that prohibited certain post-retirement employment. The plaintiff argued that this violated ERISA's anti-cutback rule, which the court upheld, stating that any amendment imposing greater restrictions on benefit receipt reduces the accrued benefit. ERISA prohibits age discrimination in benefit accrual for defined benefit and defined contribution plans. Courts have evaluated cash balance plans for age discrimination due to the structure of pay and interest credits. The PPA amended ERISA to address age discrimination in benefit accrual for cash balance plans. While some district court decisions found these plans to be discriminatory, appellate courts have ruled otherwise. The act established new standards to determine if a plan is age discriminatory, stating that a participant's accrued benefit must be at least equal to that of a similarly situated, younger individual to be considered non-discriminatory. The PPA amended ERISA to address age discrimination in benefit accrual for cash balance plans. A "similarly situated" individual must have benefits equal to that of the participant, except for age. Benefits must be fully vested after three years, with interest credits not exceeding a market rate of return. New provisions are effective from June 29, 2005, and plans existing before may face legal challenges. Vested benefits can be received once accrued, ensuring nonforfeitable rights for retirement benefits. The participant may receive vested retirement benefits even if leaving the job before retirement. Vesting requirements apply to employer contributions only. ERISA imposes age and service-based vesting requirements for normal retirement benefits. The plan must specify a normal retirement age for vesting purposes. ERISA requires retirement benefits to vest based on age or years of service, with two vesting schedules for defined benefit plans. Defined contribution plans have different vesting requirements, with exceptions for certain plans where participants are immediately vested in employer contributions. Under ERISA rules, retirement benefits must vest based on age or years of service. There are two vesting schedules for defined benefit plans, including cliff vesting and graduated vesting. Cliff vesting requires 100% vesting after three years, while graduated vesting requires 20% after two years, increasing to 100% after six years. Both employer matching and nonelective contributions must vest. ERISA protects against losing credit for earlier service if an employee leaves and returns within five years. The vesting rules under ERISA require that all service before becoming a plan participant be considered for vesting purposes. Nonvested participants must also count years of service before any break in service upon re-employment. A break in service occurs if an employee completes less than 500 hours of service in a year. Workers typically do not incur a break in service for up to one year due to specific reasons like pregnancy or adoption. The Retirement Equity Act of 1984 increased pension protections for survivors. The Retirement Equity Act of 1984 (REA) amended ERISA to increase pension protections for survivors of deceased plan participants. ERISA requires defined benefit plans to provide survivor annuities to married employees, honor qualified domestic relations orders (QDROs) in case of divorce, and provide survivor annuities to spouses of vested participants. The preretirement survivor annuity can be paid by the employer or passed on to participants. Both participant and spouse must sign a waiver form to waive the benefit. Profit-sharing and stock bonus plans must automatically pay the vested account balance to the spouse upon the participant's death unless an alternate beneficiary is designated. Defined benefit plans must provide a joint and survivor annuity as the default form of benefit for married participants. Beginning in 2008, the PPA requires defined benefit plans to offer a 75% survivor annuity option if the plan's survivor annuity is less than 75%, and a 50% survivor annuity option if it is greater than 75%. Waiving the survivor benefit requires written consent from both the participant and spouse, with a minimum of 90 days before the annuity starting date. Joint and survivor annuities are based on the joint life expectancy of the participant and spouse, resulting in lower payouts compared to single-life annuities. The REA of 1984 amended ERISA to allow plans to honor state court orders awarding a share of a worker's pension to a former spouse through qualified domestic relations orders (QDRO). ERISA sets procedures for plan administrators to determine the validity of a QDRO. A qualified domestic relations order (QDRO) allows pension plans to provide benefits to a former spouse of a participant. It must specify details such as names, addresses, amounts, and plans involved. The order should not require the plan to provide additional benefits or pay more than it would have without the order. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) directed the Secretary of Labor to issue regulations clarifying the qualification of domestic relations orders that supersede or revise earlier QDROs. In the event of a company acquisition, pension benefits for participants and beneficiaries must be maintained, and PBGC insurance protections apply. In cases of plan mergers or transfers, participant benefits must be preserved or increased compared to pre-merger levels. This ensures adequate funds for promised pension benefits. ERISA requires plan sponsors to fully fund pension liabilities of defined benefit plans to ensure payment of promised benefits. The PPA modified funding rules, allowing for amortization of liabilities over time. Single-employer plans must amortize past service liabilities over seven years. Defined contribution plans have no funding requirements. Employers must fund pension benefits earned each year, known as the normal cost. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) requires defined benefit plan sponsors to fully fund pension liabilities each year. This includes funding the normal cost of the plan and amortizing past service liabilities. Assets must be held in a separate trust to protect them from creditors in case of bankruptcy. If a plan is underfunded, the sponsor must amortize the unfunded liability over time. The PPA established new rules for determining full funding and required contributions. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) requires defined benefit plan sponsors to fully fund pension liabilities each year, including the normal cost of the plan and past service liabilities. Assets must be held in a separate trust to protect them from creditors. New rules determine full funding and required contributions, effective for plan years starting in 2008. Determining if a pension is adequately funded involves converting future payments into present value to compare with plan assets. An underfunded plan has assets below liabilities' present value. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) requires plan sponsors to fully fund pension liabilities each year. Future payments must be discounted using an appropriate interest rate. New funding requirements mandate plan assets to equal 100% of plan liabilities. Unfunded liability must be amortized over a maximum of seven years. Sponsors of severely underfunded plans face special rules for higher contributions. Credit balances can offset contributions if the plan is funded at 80% or more. The value of credit balances must be adjusted to reflect changes in the market value of plan assets since contributions were made. A plan sponsor's minimum required contribution is based on the plan's target normal cost and the funding target. If a plan's assets are less than the funding target, the plan has an unfunded liability that must be amortized over a maximum of seven years. The minimum required annual contribution is the plan's target normal cost for the year. The annual contribution is the plan's target normal cost for the year, with a 100% funding target being phased in over several years. ERISA requires plans to discount future liabilities using different interest rates based on the time until payment. Short-term, mid-term, and long-term interest rates are used for liabilities due within five years, five to 20 years, and over 20 years, respectively. The rates are determined by the Secretary of the Treasury based on a yield curve of investment-grade corporate bonds. The yield curve of investment-grade corporate bonds, phased in over three years starting in 2007, replaces the four-year average of corporate bond rates from the Pension Funding Equity Act of 2004. Pension plans at risk of defaulting must use specific actuarial assumptions to determine liabilities. Plans failing to meet funding tests are considered at-risk unless funded at least 80%. The minimum funding requirement for pension plans will be phased in over four years, starting at 65% in 2008 and rising to 80% in 2011. Plans failing to meet funding tests are considered at-risk unless funded at least 80%. Plans at risk for at least two of the previous four years will be subject to an additional "loading factor" added to the plan sponsor's required contribution. Plans with 500 or fewer participants are exempt from at-risk funding requirements. The actuaries of a pension plan estimate future obligations using mortality tables to project participants' claims and payment duration. ERISA mandates Treasury-prescribed mortality tables, with large plans able to request a plan-specific table. Prior to the PPA, plan sponsors could value assets using actuarial valuations, smoothing investment returns over five years to reduce volatility caused by interest rate fluctuations. The PPA introduced changes to actuarial valuations for pension plans, narrowing the range for valuations and reducing the maximum smoothing period to two years. Plans with over 100 participants must use the first day of the plan year for calculations, while smaller plans have flexibility. Plan sponsors can offset current contributions with previous ones, but only if assets are at least 80% of the funding target. The PPA requires assets to be at least 80% of the funding target, excluding prefunding balances. Credit balances must be adjusted for investment gains and losses, separated by year. ERISA limits plan amendments, benefit accruals, and distribution options for underfunded defined benefit plans. Shutdown benefits are paid when a plant closes. ERISA prohibits shut-down benefits and other "contingent event benefits" from being paid by pension plans funded at less than 60% of full funding. The PBGC guarantee for such benefits is phased in over a five-year period. Benefit accruals must cease in plans funded below 60% of full funding, with decisions on past service accruals made once funding is above 60%. Additional contributions prescribed by statute can exempt plans from these requirements. Section 203 of WRERA addresses plan years beginning on or after October 1. Section 203 of WRERA allows pension plans to use the previous year's funding levels to determine benefit accrual restrictions for the first plan year starting from October 1, 2008, through September 30, 2009. Plans with funding below 80% cannot increase benefits without additional contributions, and lump-sum distributions are prohibited below 60% funding level. ERISA mandates restrictions on distributions from underfunded pension plans based on funding levels. Plans below 60% or in bankruptcy with less than 100% funding are prohibited from distributions. Plans between 60% and 80% funding can only distribute up to half of the accrued benefit as a lump sum. Participants must be notified of any restrictions within 30 days. Defined benefit pensions must offer the option of a life annuity or a lump sum at separation from the employer. The lump-sum distribution from a defined benefit pension is determined by the interest rate used to calculate the present value of the accrued benefit. ERISA mandates using specific interest rates and mortality tables to protect employees' benefits. The PPA amended ERISA to require lump-sum payments to be based on corporate bond interest rates. Plans using higher interest rates for larger lump sums must treat them as a subsidy to participants. The new rules for lump-sum distributions are being phased in over five years, starting in 2008. Minimum permissible lump-sum payments will be based on a three-segment interest rate yield curve derived from investment-grade corporate bond rates. Older workers will receive larger lump sums than younger workers due to the use of different interest rates based on age. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) introduced new rules for lump-sum distributions, with rates based on current bond rates. Plans funded below 60% cannot pay lump sums, while those funded at 60% to 80% can pay up to half of a participant's benefit. The PPA also set an interest rate floor for lump sum calculations under IRC §415(b), limiting annual annuity payments. Plans must use an interest rate of at least 5.5% or the highest of specified rates for this calculation. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) established new rules for improving the funding of multiemployer defined benefit plans in "endangered" or "critical" status. Plans must use an interest rate of at least 5.5% or the highest specified rate for lump sum calculations. Multiemployer plans are collectively bargained plans maintained by multiple employers and a labor union, subject to different funding requirements than single-employer plans. ERISA requires each multiemployer plan to certify its funding status and project funding for the next six years within 90 days of the plan year start. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) established new rules for improving the funding of multiemployer defined benefit plans in "endangered" or "critical" status. Plans must certify their funding status and project funding for the next six years within 90 days of the plan year start. If underfunded, plans have 30 days to notify participants and eight months to develop a funding schedule meeting statutory requirements. The PPA increased the limit on tax-deductible employer contributions to multiemployer plans to 140% of the plan's current liability and eliminated the 25%-of-compensation combined limit on contributions to defined benefit and defined contribution plans. The Pension Protection Act (PPA) established rules to improve funding for seriously underfunded multiemployer plans. Plans with a funding deficiency within seven years are considered endangered and must implement a recovery plan. Plans less than 80% funded have 10 years to improve their funding. Endangered plans must reduce underfunding and improve funding percentage by one-third. Plans that are seriously endangered and less than 70% funded have 15 years to improve their funding by one-fifth of the difference between 100% funding and the plan's funded percentage. Endangered or seriously endangered plans may not increase benefits if the parties cannot agree on a funding improvement plan. A multiemployer plan is considered to be in critical status if it is less than 65% funded and has a projected funding deficiency within five years or will be unable to pay benefits within seven years. Plans in critical status must develop a rehabilitation plan within one year to reduce underfunding. The PPA relaxed ERISA's anti-cutback rule for multiemployer plans in critical status, allowing reductions in early retirement subsidies and other adjustable benefits to improve funding. Normal retirement age benefits cannot be reduced, and plans cannot cut benefits for participants who retired before being notified of critical status. Adjustable benefits include certain optional forms of payment, disability benefits, early retirement benefits, joint and survivor annuities, and recent benefit increases. The PPA amended ERISA for multiemployer plans in critical status, requiring funding notices to be sent to participants within 120 days. Plans must provide information on request, certify funding improvement schedules, and notify relevant parties within 30 days of critical status. ERISA imposes obligations on plan fiduciaries. ERISA Section 3(21)(A) defines a fiduciary as someone who has authority over plan management or assets, provides investment advice for a fee, or has administrative responsibilities. Fiduciaries must be named in the plan document, and they owe duties of loyalty, prudence, diversification, and compliance with plan documents under ERISA Section 404(a)(1). ERISA requires plan fiduciaries to act in the best interest of participants and beneficiaries, avoiding conflicts of interest. Engaging in transactions that benefit the fiduciary or a third party does not always constitute a breach of fiduciary duty, as seen in Donovan v. Bierwirth case involving pension plan trustees who were also corporate officers. In Donovan v. Bierwirth, pension plan trustees breached their fiduciary duties by deciding against tendering company stock during a hostile takeover attempt and purchasing additional stock for the plan. The court emphasized that decisions must prioritize the interests of participants and beneficiaries, not the corporation or fiduciaries themselves. The Department of Labor requires plan fiduciaries to assess service providers objectively, monitor their qualifications, work quality, and fees. A final regulation issued in 2007 revises Form 5500 to disclose fees paid to plan administrators and service providers. The Department of Labor published a proposed regulation in 2007 requiring service providers to disclose all fees and compensation to plan fiduciaries. Fiduciaries must act prudently and courts examine the process taken in decision-making regarding plan assets. Success or failure of an investment may not be relevant to a fiduciary's duty of prudence. The Department of Labor regulations clarify the duty of prudence in investment decisions under ERISA. Fiduciaries must consider relevant facts and circumstances, ensuring investments are designed to further the plan's purposes while considering risk, diversification, liquidity, and return. The duty of prudence in investment decisions under ERISA requires fiduciaries to consider risk, diversification, liquidity, and return when investing the plan's portfolio to minimize the risk of large losses. ERISA Section 404(a)(1)(C) does not set fixed criteria for diversification but mandates a case-specific determination. In GIW Industries, Inc. v. Trevor Stewart, the court found that the defendant breached duty by investing heavily in long-term government bonds, exposing the fund to excessive risk. Expert testimony suggested that investing in short-term bonds or bonds with staggered maturity dates would have minimized risk. Similarly, in Brock v. Citizens Bank of Clovis, trustees breached duty by investing over 65% of assets in commercial real estate mortgages, leading to a lack of diversification. The court found that trustees breached their duty by investing heavily in one type of security, exposing the plan to multiple risks. Despite the lack of diversification, in Metzler v. Graham, a trustee was not found to have breached duty for investing over half of the plan's assets in one real estate piece, as the lack of diversification was deemed prudent in that case. Section 404(a)(1)(D) of ERISA requires fiduciaries to act in accordance with the plan documents, as long as they are consistent with ERISA. Courts have interpreted Section 404(a)(1)(D) of ERISA to apply to various writings that impact a plan, such as investment management agreements and collective bargaining agreements. Fiduciaries must disregard plan provisions that conflict with ERISA, even if compliance would breach other fiduciary duties. The Department of Labor argues that fiduciaries must ignore provisions that require imprudent or disloyal actions. This issue was highlighted in Tittle v. Enron. In Tittle v. Enron, the court held that plan fiduciaries have a duty to disregard provisions that would be imprudent to follow. Courts have also found that fiduciaries do not breach their duty if they make good faith errors in interpreting plan documents, as seen in Morgan v. Independent Drivers Association Pension Plan. ERISA prohibits fiduciaries from engaging in specified transactions likely to harm a pension plan, with Section 406(a) barring certain transactions between a plan and a party in interest. Fiduciaries must avoid causing a plan to engage in transactions involving property sales, lending money, providing goods or services, transferring plan assets, or acquiring assets on behalf of the plan. ERISA prohibits certain transactions between a pension plan and parties in interest to prevent harm to the plan. This includes restrictions on dealing with plan assets for personal gain, acting on behalf of conflicting parties, and limits on investing in employer securities or property. The ERISA prohibits transactions between pension plans and parties in interest to prevent harm. Section 407 restricts plans from investing in employer securities or real property unless they are qualifying. Plans cannot hold more than 10% of employer securities or property. Defined contribution plans have new diversification requirements for employer securities under the PPA. Section 204(j) of ERISA allows individuals to divest employee contributions and elective deferrals invested in employer securities and reinvest in other options. Plans must offer at least three alternative investment options for diversification. Employees with three years of service can also diversify employer matching and nonelective contributions out of employer stock. This requirement is phased in over three years for existing contributions before 2007. Plans cannot impose restrictions, except as provided in regulations. ERISA allows individuals to divest and reinvest in other options, with plans required to offer diversification options. Employees with three years of service can diversify employer contributions out of stock, phased in over three years before 2007. Plans cannot impose restrictions on employer stock investment not imposed on other investments. The Labor Department grants exemptions for certain individuals and classes, ensuring feasibility and protection of participants' rights. Prior to the PPA, ERISA's prohibited transaction restrictions discouraged investment advice provision due to the broad categories of prohibited transactions. The PPA amended ERISA to address this issue and provide exemptions for certain transactions, including loans to participants, reasonable arrangements with parties in interest, certain plan investments, and the purchase of insurance from a qualifying insurer. The PPA amended ERISA to provide a statutory prohibited transaction exemption for investment advice, allowing fiduciaries to provide advice without fear of liability. This exemption applies to transactions involving investment advice provided by a fiduciary adviser under an "eligible investment advice arrangement." The PPA amended ERISA to provide a prohibited transaction exemption for investment advice, allowing fiduciaries to provide advice under an "eligible investment advice arrangement." This arrangement must meet specific requirements, including authorization by a plan fiduciary, annual audits, disclosure requirements, and clear participant notifications. Under ERISA, fiduciaries can provide investment advice under an "eligible investment advice arrangement" with specific requirements such as authorization, audits, disclosure, and clear participant notifications. Section 404(c) provides immunity for fiduciaries if participants have control over their account assets, but certain requirements must be met for the plan to qualify as a "404(c) plan." Labor Department regulations outline the criteria for a plan to be considered a "404(c) plan," including providing participants with control over their account assets. The ERISA regulations require that individuals have the opportunity to control their account assets and make informed investment decisions. Plans must offer a broad range of diversified investment alternatives, with at least three options that differ in risk and return characteristics. Participants must be able to materially affect the potential return and risk of their account. The ERISA regulations mandate that participants have the ability to control their account assets and make informed investment choices. Plans must provide diverse investment options with varying risk and return profiles to help participants achieve a suitable portfolio. Fiduciaries can avoid liability under Section 404(c) if participants exercise independent control over their investments. Personal liability may arise if fiduciaries breach their duties under ERISA Section 409. Section 409 of ERISA holds fiduciaries accountable for any losses resulting from breaches of duty, with potential forfeiture of profits made through improper use of plan assets. Courts may award monetary and equitable relief as needed. Fiduciaries are not liable for breaches committed before or after their fiduciary role, but may be responsible for rectifying previous breaches. ERISA aims to protect participants' interests and ensure diverse investment options for suitable portfolios. ERISA aims to protect participants' interests and ensure diverse investment options for suitable portfolios. It provides for appropriate remedies, sanctions, and access to Federal courts through an integrated enforcement mechanism. Section 502 allows private parties and government entities to bring civil actions to enforce ERISA provisions and remedies. The actions that can be brought under ERISA's enforcement scheme include redressing failures of plan administrators, recovering benefits, enforcing rights, obtaining relief for fiduciary breaches, enjoining violations, and collecting civil penalties. Section 502 provides exclusive federal remedies and may preempt state law. Under the doctrine of complete preemption, state law claims that conflict with federal statutory schemes in ERISA can be removed to federal court. If a state law claim falls within ERISA's Section 502(a) civil enforcement provisions, it is completely preempted, limiting the plaintiff to remedies available under federal law. The Supreme Court has evaluated claims under Section 502 of ERISA, which allows plaintiffs to bring actions against plans to recover benefits or enforce their rights. If benefits are denied, plaintiffs can sue for unpaid benefits, seek declarations for future benefits, or obtain injunctions. A plaintiff under Section 502 of ERISA can seek a declaration for future benefits or an injunction to prevent benefit denial. Section 502(a)(1)(B) allows successful plaintiffs to receive entitled benefits, excluding compensatory or punitive damages. This section preempts state law claims, sparking controversy over the limitation of damages available. The issue of preemption of state law claims by ERISA 502(a)(1)(B) has been contentious and closely examined by the courts. The Supreme Court in Pilot Life v. Dedeaux evaluated whether a state law claim for wrongful denial of benefits was preempted by Sections 514 and 502 of ERISA. The plaintiffs claimed that denial of disability benefits violated Mississippi common law relating to bad faith. The Court found the state law claim preempted by Section 502, stating that ERISA's civil enforcement provisions are the exclusive means for addressing benefit denials. The Supreme Court evaluated whether state law claims for wrongful denial of benefits were preempted by ERISA in Aetna Health Inc. v. Davila. The issue was whether individual causes of action were preempted by ERISA, leading to removal to federal court. Respondents argued that their state law claim would undermine the federal scheme if allowed. The Supreme Court ruled that state law claims for wrongful denial of benefits were not preempted by ERISA in Aetna Health Inc. v. Davila. Respondents' claim for violating the "duty of ordinary care" was found to be solely related to ERISA-regulated plans, not an independent legal duty.
